I did this by accident once. Some aspirin in the bottom of a large test tube covered with 70% IPA. 70% full. I (carefully) heated the bottom with a propane torch. Eventually, there was a SNAP and big bubble occurred. The liquid itself wasn't boiling, but the cavitation must have caused the bonds to break. You could smell vinegar, and my crystals were 1" needles instead of the expected. Everything else precipitated out. I've not seen anyone else ever use this localized heating to produce cavitation in a vessel to break chemical bonds. Give it a try. It's hell of a lot easier than screwing around with acids.

I decided to extract ASA from asprin. Once I had done that I sort of forgot about it in the flask and when I came back it had a strong smell of acetic acid. I believe my ASA had decomposed into salicylic acid and acetic acid (as there was a liquid in the flask that was not water). As you said in the video, esters are vulnerable to acid conditions. So I have reason to believe that once the acetic acid was produced it continued the reaction. I will still do the acid hydrolysis to ensure that all of the ASA would be converted into salicylic acid. But is there a reason that there was a strong smell of acetic acid. Thanks.

The actual commercial process to produce APAP is to start with p-nitrophenol.  This is an intermediate used in many products.  The nitro group is reacted with hydrogen to form the amine.  Then acetic acid is reacted into the molecule to form aceto-para amino phenol.  For completion, acetic anhydride is used to finish off the reaction.

Yeah I don't think some solvent extraction or recrystallization will be able to get the dye out COMPLETELY... The whole point of a dye is to impart a very strong colour at very low concentrations, so you would need some way to remove even the smallest trace of it, without losing a lot of your product. The only way that is going to happen is with a few column chromatography runs... but a better idea would be to wait until he has phenol and then just distill it slowly through a fractionating column with a fine glass sinter at the top (which, I assume, is why he didn't bother to try and purify it already).

Also, Nile, could you please, please, please consider bringing back the 60fps videos?

Hey Nile, I was wondering what you thought. I am currently trying to extract neodymium from magnets. after lots of steps, I have reason to believe I am left with Nd2O3, Fe203, and some Ni2O3. Most of the chlorides and other compounds of iron, nickel and neodymium share extremely similar properties. I referred to my merc index and it stated that neodymium sulfate is created by reacting Nd2O3 with hot concentrate H2SO4. This lead me to believe that the reaction is rather slow with dilute cold acid. The iron and Nickel salts should dissolve in dilute acid however. I was wondering if you would give my your input... If this does work, I can react the Nd2O3 that didn't dissolve with HCl and electrolyse the chloride formed to obtain the pure metal. Parts of this are my own processes, so if this works, It could be a new viable way to recycle neodymium magnets. I am only 15 and LOVE chemistry, Please respond. You have one of the neatest chemistry channels of all time. :)
